answers.title: Subscribing to an empty Flux causes an infinite loop
answers.body:
Since I have not received an answer (as usual, I might add), I have created a workaround.

First, I collect the response in a list, then use Flux.error() and then complete the execution with onErrorComplete() in the caller.

public Flux<ListItem> create(List<ListItem> originalList) {
    return repository.get()
    .collectList()
    .flatMapMany(list -> {
        if(list.isEmpty()) return Flux.error(new IllegalStateException());
        return repository.saveAll(list);
    })
    .switchIfEmpty(repository.saveAll(originalList)
    .onErrorComplete();

Since my flatMapMany() relies on an initial database call, I additionally use switchIfEmpty() to catch any situation with an empty response. This does not necessarily fit every use case, but may be relevant for the types of problems that may result in an empty Flux.

items.title: Subscribing to an empty Flux causes an infinite loop
items.body:
I have a call chain that looks something like this:

public ResponseEntity<Flux<Entity>> create() {
    return ResponseEntity.ok(saveList());
}

public Flux<Entity> saveList() {
    if(list.isEmpty()) return Flux.empty();
    return repository.saveAll(list);
}

Whether I return Flux.empty() directly or send it to the database call, if I add a .map() call onto the create() chain, it does not execute because there are no elements, as we would expect. However, if I add a .switchIfEmpty(), this also does not execute. No matter what combination of handlers I have tried for an empty Flux, it always results in an infinite loop, I assume because it's waiting for an element to be added so it can emit it.

The documentation suggests Flux.empty() should complete without emitting anything, but logging the Flux shows only onSubscribe() and request() are called, so it is not completing, hence why the .switchIfEmpty() is also not called.

What do I need to do to get an empty Flux to complete when I subscribe to it?

Any non-zero-sized Flux succeeds, but I have tried a number of different empty Flux types, such as from an array, which all fail.

I am using a hard-coded, non empty Publisher for switchIfEmpty(), since the implication seems to be that this is strictly necessary.

comments.body_markdown: Stop mixing versions of different modules from a framework. You are mixing 2.7 and 3.0 from spring boot that won't work. You also appear to have some ancient versions of `commons-dbcp` on your classpath probably pulled in by one of your dependencies.
comments.body: Stop mixing versions of different modules from a framework. You are mixing 2.7 and 3.0 from spring boot that won't work. You also appear to have some ancient versions of commons-dbcp on your classpath probably pulled in by one of your dependencies.

comments.body_markdown: Thanks, can you clarify which modules I am mixing? for commons-dbcp how I can identify where I need to update the version or find the class to fix it? honestly I am not sure what is commons-dbcp used for.
comments.body: Thanks, can you clarify which modules I am mixing? for commons-dbcp how I can identify where I need to update the version or find the class to fix it? honestly I am not sure what is commons-dbcp used for.

comments.body_markdown: Your `spring-boot-starter-cache` has version 3.0.0 which is a different version and thus will pull in other dependencies with incompatible things as well. RUle of thumb don't use version tags for `spring-boot-starter` dependencies, those are management by the parent. Your error is about commons-dbcp (a datasource) do a `mvn dependency:tree` to see what is pulling that in.
comments.body: Your spring-boot-starter-cache has version 3.0.0 which is a different version and thus will pull in other dependencies with incompatible things as well. RUle of thumb don't use version tags for spring-boot-starter dependencies, those are management by the parent. Your error is about commons-dbcp (a datasource) do a mvn dependency:tree to see what is pulling that in.

comments.body_markdown: I have checked the mvn tree and the lib folder I could not find the commons-dbcp. I am not sure how is this being added now. Could the error resulted from not having the file in the lib folder?
comments.body: I have checked the mvn tree and the lib folder I could not find the commons-dbcp. I am not sure how is this being added now. Could the error resulted from not having the file in the lib folder?

comments.body_markdown: No it indicates there is an old version in there, due to the abstract method error. Which means you have a newer API but an older implementation. The problem is you are deploying to Tomcat and not running the embedded container, tomcat ships with a version of commons DBCP. I suspect that is the issue and that the version of Tomca tyou are deploying to is unsupported. You need at least tomcat 8.5 if memory serves me well for Spring Boot 2.7 or even 9.
comments.body: No it indicates there is an old version in there, due to the abstract method error. Which means you have a newer API but an older implementation. The problem is you are deploying to Tomcat and not running the embedded container, tomcat ships with a version of commons DBCP. I suspect that is the issue and that the version of Tomca tyou are deploying to is unsupported. You need at least tomcat 8.5 if memory serves me well for Spring Boot 2.7 or even 9.

comments.body_markdown: Thanks, I believe you are correct. after a lot of digging, I found that the project was running on tomcat 9 locally and we have tomcat 7 on the server. I have added both versions in the STS and it only ran on tomcat 9. Thanks for your help M. Deinum.
comments.body: Thanks, I believe you are correct. after a lot of digging, I found that the project was running on tomcat 9 locally and we have tomcat 7 on the server. I have added both versions in the STS and it only ran on tomcat 9. Thanks for your help M. Deinum.

answers.title: How to fix " java: package org.junit.jupiter.api does not exist "
answers.body:
You have to add the dependency to your class path. If you are using maven add:

<!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.junit.jupiter/junit-jupiter-api -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
    <version>5.9.2</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>

to your pom.xml

comments.body_markdown: IMO, the truly smart way to do it is to not do it at all.  Suffixes like K and M are ambiguous.  (If the Java designers thought this kind of thing was a good idea, they would have included in the language syntax.  I can't think of *any* mainstream programming language that supports scaling suffixes ... other than standard E (scientific) notation.)

comments.body_markdown: Anyhow, I don't think there is a way to do this that is any sense "easy" or "smart".
comments.body: Anyhow, I don't think there is a way to do this that is any sense "easy" or "smart".

comments.body_markdown: Well the OP could do that, but overall I don't think they will improve their code by doing that.  And besides, there is the small problem that in some contexts "k" means 1024 rather than 1000.  So using "k" as short-hand in your code ... and in your written communications in general ... is potentially ambiguous.  When you are talking to human beings, they will typically disambiguate from the context.  But compilers are not that smart.

answers.title: Easy and Smart Amounts String/int using java
answers.body:
You may want to try something like this:

class Amounts {

    public static int k(int amount){
        return amount * 1_000;
    }
    
    public static int M(int amount){
        return amount * 1_000_000;
    }
    
    (...)
}

And then you could use it like this:

new Item(ItemList.COINS, Amounts.M(1));
new Item(ItemList.FISH, Amounts.k(2));

However, I personally prefer just using constants (and inserting _ after three digits) like:

new Item(ItemList.COINS, 1_000_000);

Or something like

new Item(ItemList.COINS, 1 * Amounts.MILLION);

(and define a static constant public static int MILLION = 1_000_000; in class Amounts)

answers.title: Easy and Smart Amounts String/int using java
answers.body:
You can use below function to convert number into your format and can use in your code with some changes as per your requirement -

    public static String formatNumber(double value) {
    String suf = " kmbt";
    NumberFormat formatter = new DecimalFormat("#,###.#");

    int power = (int)StrictMath.log10(value);
    value = value/(Math.pow(10,(power/3)*3));
    String result =formatter.format(value);
    result  = result  + suf.charAt(power/3);
    return result .length()>4 ?  result .replaceAll("\\.[0-9]+", "") : result ;
}

<dependency>

</dependency>
